text: The sky is overlaid with the slow whup-whup-whup of an LA helicopter flashing through the frame, here and gone. LAPD radio transmissions crackle like static electricity around a dirty clapboard bungalow that looks like the puckered asshole of Eagle Rock. A man's terrified voice screams invisibly from the house

I'm gonna kill this dog!  You make my wife talk to me or I'm gonna shoot this fuckin' dog! A five-member SWAT tactical team appears out of nowhere-- black assault gear, M5s, gloved and masked--hustling into position on either side of the front door.  Only now do w get the full picture:  Helicopters overhead, radio cars surrounding the house, an army of cops itching the pull t trigger -- When the tac team is good to go, the team leader gives a thumbs-up to --

head_text.subj: SERGEANT JEFF TALLEY AND LT. MURRAY LEIFITZ

text: Talley and Leifitz are hunkered behind the LAPD Command a Control van.  Leifitz is the Crisis Response Team SWAT  commander; Talley, the primary negotiator.  It's so hot o here that Talley has stripped down to a tee-shirt and ves
They're good to go, Talley.  Your word, and we're in the house.
No one's going anywhere, L-T.  We can talk this guy down. Talley lifts a dedicated crisis phone that's been hardlin into the house, his tone reasonable and friendly --
(into the phone) Hey, George?  George, don't kill the dog, okay?  We don't want to hear a gun go off in there. A phone crashes through the window and lands in the front yard --
(screaming from the house) Fuck you!
I don't think he wants to talk. Frustrated, Talley slumps back against the van as the SWA Intelligence Officer, Lloyd Keith, scuttles up to them --
Where's the guy's wife?
She didn't take the kid to her sister's. The neighbors were wrong.
Goddamnit, you said we had her.  I told him we had her!

We got bad information, Talley.  I can't pull her out of my ass! Up at the house, George Edward Malik steps into the windo Malik is a forty-year-old freaked-out loser who has turne the corner on insanity --

(shouting at Talley) You said my wife was gonna talk to me, you lying fuck!  I'm gonna kill her dog, then shoot myself!  I mean it! Talley stares at Malik, thinking, then abruptly grabs Kei by the collar --
(to Keith) Pull the dog's name out of your ass.  Get the dog's name. Talley steps out from behind the command van so that Mali can see him.
(alarmed by Talley's move) Talley!  You're in the line of fire! Talley ignores Leifitz; he is totally focused on Malik an defusing the situation --
I didn't lie to you, George.  You scared your wife pretty good last night.  We're having a hard time finding her.
She better talk to me!  I'm gonna kill her goddamned dog!
You and I have been talking for, what,  sixteen hours?  Keep talking.  Is that your dog, too? Malik steps away from the window --
I don't know whose dog it is.  She lied about everything else, so she probably lied about the dog.
I know you're hurting.  You lose your job, you find out your wife's fucking another guy . . . but don't give up. We'll have her talk to you.
Then why won't she open her mouth?!  Why doesn't the bitch say something???  Something about Malik's statement bothers Talley.  The wording is odd, suspicious --
George?  Come back to the window.
Talley grows even more concerned.  Was Malik talking to h
George?  Leave the dog alone and come to the window. Talley sees Keith rejoin Leifitz --
(to Leifitz) What's the dog's name?
The neighbors say he doesn't have a dog. The pieces fall into place for Talley:  The wife that no can find, the dog that doesn't exist....

head_text.subj: OPEN YOUR GODDAMNED MOUTH OR I'M GONNA

text: In a single terrible moment, Talley realizes that Malik i not talking to him; he's talking to his wife --

Murray!!  They're in the house!  His wife's in the house! Even as Talley screams, a gunshot echoes from the house, freezing the moment.  A second shot follows the first as tactical team breaches the front door -- Talley sprints forward, running as hard as he can in nightmare slow motion --

Talley shoulders inside on the heels of the tactical team through drifting gun smoke and lancing sunlight.  SWAT co are cuffing Malik even though he's already dead of a self inflicted gunshot wound; Malik's wife is sprawled on the couch where she has been dead for fourteen hours; two tac officers are trying to stop the geyser of arterial blood sprays from the neck of Malik's nine-year-old son even as of them screams for the paramedics -- Talley is numb; it's all too much, too heavy, too horribl He kneels between to the tactical cops and takes the boy' hand.  He stares into the boy's eyes, and the boy stares back.  The child's face grows pale as he drains of blood. hear his heart beating.  We hear it slow.  We hear it sto Talley stares at the dead boy.  The dead boy's lifeless e stare at nothing.
Another hyperblue sky, but now we're in an upscale bedroo community in the sun-scorched high desert north of LA -- A legend appears:  One Year Later.

A rotted-out Toyota pickup lurches to a stop alongside th minimart, white-boy hip-hop booming on the radio which di with the engine -- Dennis Rooney is driving; twenty-three years old, working class desert trash with a high opinion of his own broodin good looks.  In the middle: Kevin Rooney, nineteen, scare shitless at what they're about to do.  Riding shotgun:  M Krupchek, twenty-four, a large pasty guy with a shaved he and faraway eyes.
C'mon, Dennis, this is stupid.  I thought we were gonna go to the movies.
(grins past Kevin to Mars) Mars?!  Whattaya think, dude?  Out here on the edge, no one around, it's perfect, right?
I'll check it out. Mars slides out of the truck.  He has a tattoo on the bac his tattoo that says:  BURN IT. As soon as Mars is gone, Dennis frowns at Kevin --
Try to act cool, okay?  He's gonna think you're a dick.
Robbing this place is gonna put you back in prison.
Not if they don't catch us, Kevin.
We got jobs, man; we're working.  Why even take the chance?
Because if you don't take the chance, you're already dead. Dennis pulls a pistol from his pants to check the magazin
Thirty seconds, we'll be down the road. Thirty seconds.  Then we'll go to the movies. Mars returns and nods his approval --
It's perfect. That's all it takes.

Junior Kim, Jr., is short, squat, and forty-two years old He's reading a magazine behind the counter when Dennis an Mars enter; Dennis trying to disarm him with a smile -- As Dennis reaches the counter, he lifts his tee-shirt to reveal the butt of his pistol --
A pack of Marlboros for my friend and all your cash, you gook motherfucker! But Junior Kim is ready.  He lurches to his feet, bringin a pistol of his own --
He's got a gun! Dennis lunges across the counter, grabbing Kim's gun, and two men are suddenly locked in a ferocious death-struggle possession of the weapon --

Mars, help me -- Dennis and Kim bounce from the counter to the Slurpy mach the Glock locked between them, pointing first one way, th the other, their eyes meeting as -- BAM -- the gun goes o Junior Kim's eyes widen.  Dennis and Junior both look dow the red blossom that grows on Junior Kim's chest --

(screaming in the background) Dennis!  Dennis, someone's coming! Kim falls into the Slurpy machine, then slides to the flo Dennis scrambles over the counter and sprints for the doo But Mars hesitates.  Instead of running, he picks up Kim' gun, then leans over the counter to look at Kim's body. cannot see his face --

A forty-something soccer mom named Margaret Hammond is ab to enter the minimart when Dennis and Kevin burst out, knocking her on her ass.  Mars follows a moment later -- Margaret watches their red pickup lurch away, then rushes into the store --
Dennis power-shifts into gear, clashing tortured metal as pushes the Toyota as hard as it will go.  No one is talki they're screaming --
There's fuckin' blood all over you!
I didn't know he would have a gun!  It just went off! Dennis sees himself in the rearview mirror.  His face is  splattered with red dew, the sight of it freaking him out
Jesus!  Fuckin' Jesus, it's on my face! The trunk careens crazily off the road.  Mars calmly runs hand over Dennis's face --
Relax.  It's only blood. Dennis upshifts hard again, the truck lurching as the tra howls --
FUCK you, Mars!  I got it all over me! -- whereupon the tortured transmission gives with a loud and the truck loses power --
MotherFUCKING piece of SHIT!!!

Flanders Road is lined with trees, hedges, and the exclus housing developments that dot the countryside around Bris Camino. The Toyota jerks to a stop well off the road, and Dennis, Mars, and Kevin pile out, stuffing pistols and bullets in their pockets --
That woman's gonna call the cops.
Shut up, goddamnit!  Just calm down!
What if he's dead?  What if you killed him? Dennis grabs him by the throat; Mars steps between them -
People are looking. Dennis sees that Mars is right; people in passing cars ar looking.  He releases his brother --
That's why we gotta keep going.  I'm not gonna go in for murder.
We're on foot.  We can't get away.
We're surrounded by houses, dumbass. Every house has a car in the garage. All we have to do is take one. Dennis and Mars take off for the wall, Kevin reluctantly following --

The camera reveals a two-story California Mediterranean h in the exclusive housing development known as York Estate You can't get in the door for less than one-point-five, a this house costs more:  Eight thousand square feet of use brick and custom tile set on a lushly landscaped acre --
You can pick them up whenever you want.
Walter Smith is at his computer behind his desk.  He's fo and fit, casually dressed with thinning hair and glasses, currently leaning back as he talks on his phone --

(into the phone) I have his corporate and personal on two disks, labeled Marlon and Al. As Smith talks, he ejects a Zip disk from his computer, attaches a label reading Al, then places it in a palm-siz case beside the first disk, Marlon --
What, you don't have a sense of humor? He's going to love it. Walter's ten-year-old son, Thomas, suddenly charges aroun the desk and pulls at his father's arm --
My stomach is eating me!
(into the phone) Yeah, that's Thomas, the human piranha. I have to feed the animals while Pam's in Florida with her sister.
My stomach has teeth!  It's eating my guts!

(still with the phone) Listen, is Glen on his way?  Great.  The paper's bagged and ready to go.  Bye. (hangs up; then) All right, all right, all right--it's  feeding time! Walter allows his son to pull him around the desk to --

A boom box blasts the latest teendiva megahit as Walter's sixteen-year-old daughter, Jennifer, stretches out in cut shorts and a bikini top, working on her tan. Walter and Thomas appear in the French doors that open fr the back of the house --
(calling) Jen!  Come feed your brother!  He's wasting away!
Can't we send him to Florida?

Jen, c'mon, chop-chop!  I've got to finish my work! Jennifer rolls her eyes, rises from the chaise longue, an pads to the house.  As she clears the frame, the camera swings toward the overgrown wall at the edge of the prope Dennis silenty drops into the bushes --
A sky blue Bristo Camino patrol car cruises along Flander Road --
Welch is a young officer with an innocence to his eyes th you don't find in urban cops.  He keeps a photo of his wi and toddler son taped to the dash.
Four, base.  You there, Mike? Welch picks up the radio microphone --
Four.  I'm gonna hit the Krispy-Kreme. You want a dozen?
Armed robbery, Kim's Minimart on Flanders Road, shots fired with a man down. This is so unexpected that Welch waits for the punchline
Are you kidding me?

Ah, suspects are three white males driving a red pickup last seen eastbound on Flanders. Welch turns on his lights just as he sees the red Toyota pickup abandoned on the side of the road and stands on hi brakes --

The Smiths' home sports an open floor plan with the kitch centrally located between a large family room, a hall tha leads to the front of the house, and the French doors tha open onto the pool area. Jennifer is putting the finishing touches on three tuna sandwiches as she calls to her brother --
Tell Daddy that lunch is ready. (no answer) Thomas, don't be a turd.  Tell --! She turns to find herself face-to-face with Dennis, who clamps a hand over her mouth --
(quietly) I'm not going to hurt you. Mars is holding Thomas.  Kevin is by the French doors --
Stop fighting.  Relax, and I'll let go. Jennifer struggles until she sees that Mars is holding a pistol to Thomas's head --

That's better.  Be cool and we'll be outta here in five minutes.  Understand? Jennifer nods, and Dennis removes his hand.  He has her pinned to the counter, his body pressed into her's; she i suddenly very aware that she is almost naked --
Who else is here?
My father. Dennis grabs her hair and pulls her away --
It happens fast:  Dennis shoves Jennifer into the room, a Mars and Kevin follow with Thomas -- Walter is feeding a computer print-out into a paper shred as they burst through the door --

Get your ass in the chair!  Sit down! Dennis shoves Jennifer to the floor and stalks directly across the room, his gun trained on Walter. Walter freezes, hands motionless, letting the paper feed the shredder.  Strangely, he has little outward reaction
(quietly) Jen?  Are you all right?
She'll be dead if you don't put your ass in that chair! Walter carefully sits.  He is amazingly calm in the face this invasion.

Kevin!  Don't stand there, asshole, close the windows!  Mars, keep him covered, dude! Mars pushes Thomas down beside Jennifer, then aims his gu Walter.  Kevin closes the shutters as Dennis rips the  electric cord from a lamp --
Who sent you?

Don't go Rambo and you'll tell'm about this on the back nine.  I'm gonna tie you up, then we're gonna take your car. Walter glances toward the shredder; the final page of pap emerges as spaghetti and then the shredder stops --
The car.  All you want is the car?
Am I talkin' raghead?!  I want your car! Gimme the goddamned keys! A strange smile flickers at the corner of Walter's mouth if there's a joke within all this, then --
The keys are on the wall by the garage. Take it.  The tank's almost full.
Dennis!  The cops! Dennis rushes to the window --
Mike Welch climbs out of the patrol car and keys his shou mike as he appraises the house --
(into his radio mike) They had to go through the yard at 455 Castle Way.  I'm going to approach. Welch slowly moves up the walk toward the front door --
Dennis shoves Jennifer to the door --
Open it!  You remember I'm right here!
Welch is halfway up the walk when the door opens and Jennifer, clearly terrified, peers out.  Welch hesitates

(into his mike) Teenage female opened the front door. (to Jennifer) Miss, I found an abandoned vehicle on the other side of your wall.  Did three young men run through the area? Jennifer doesn't answer.  Her eyes fill until two huge te roll down her cheeks.  Welch grows uneasy.  Something is wrong, but he doesn't know what.  He stays where he is --
Miss?
I didn't . . . see anyone. Welch stares into Jennifer's eyes, pointedly shifting his gaze to ask the silent question:  Are they here?
are peering out the shutters when -- Mars suddenly shouts --
He's going for his gun! Mars opens fire, shooting through the window as --
kicks the door closed and fires through the door, Jennife screaming, as --
tumbles backward, struggling weakly to pull his gun as bl bubbles in his mouth.  He tries to rise, but can't --
(into his radio) Officer down.  Jesus, I've been shot.
Mike?  Mike, what did you say?! Mike Welch blinks at the sky, but cannot answer --

It's the kind of small-town police facility you might exp A general room with desks and computers, a coffee machine and a desk officer who thinks that crime is two teenagers egging a house. The camera establishes the low-key atmosphere, during whi it finds a glass door labeled J. Talley, chief of police
Jeff Talley is behind the desk, his voice muted because h locked in a painful phone conversation --
(into phone) It's really hard, Jane.  This isn't the way I want it.
Jane Talley is an attractive woman in her mid-thirties. has the efficient manner of a registered nurse, which she and right now she's using all of her professional detachm to keep herself together --

(into phone) No?  Then whose idea was it for you take a job in the middle of nowhere? Intercut Talley, who considers the photographs that decor his wall:  Shots of Talley in happier times with Jane and their teenaged daughter, Amanda; Talley as a young SWAT officer; the framed headline from the Bristo Weekly Stand proclaiming:  EX-SWAT COP NEW BRISTO CHIEF!
I need to work out some stuff.
You're hiding, Jeffrey.  You're hiding from the job and you're hiding from me.
I still see that boy's eyes. Jane softens; she knows that a part of him is in terrible pain.  But she's in pain, too --

That happened a year ago.  You've been gone for almost six months.  How long do you have to punish yourself for something that wasn't your fault? Talley studies the picture of his wife and daughter.  He focuses on Amanda --
Is Amanda there? Jane cups the phone and calls to her daughter.  Amanda en and goes to the refrigerator.  She's fifteen and carrying weight of a seriously bad attitude --
(to Amanda) It's Dad.  He wants to speak with you.
(doesn't even glance over) I'm gonna see him later.
(back to Talley) She has to go to the bathroom. Jane turns away and lowers her voice, not wanting Amanda
You're not only punishing yourself, Jeff. Amanda and I are in this, too. Talley knows, and he hurts like hell because of it --
Can we talk some more when you get here?
We'll see you in a couple of hours. Jane hangs up without waiting for a response, then closes eyes, trying hard to keep herself together.
I don't wanna go up there.  I want to  stay here with my friends.
Pack your things.  You're going. Jane stalks away without a glance back, and Amanda angril flips off her mother --
He is clearly shaken by the call, but his thoughts are interrupted when his assistant, an older woman named Loui Vance, bursts in --
Mike's been shot!  Someone shot Junior Kim, too -- Talley comes around his desk --
What are you talking about, shot?  What happened?
Three white males shot Junior.  Mike followed them to York Estates --
Where are they?
York Estates.  Four-five-five Castle Way. Anders and Jorgenson are on the way. Talley charges out --

Talley wheels into a wide, spacious cul-de-sac lined with expensive estate homes, and pulls up behind another radio car.  Anders and Jorgenson are crouched in the street -- Bullets snap into Talley's windshield, starring the glass
Sonofabitch. Talley scrambles out of his car --

Talley takes cover behind his front wheel.  Anders and Jorgenson are young guys; they've never worked a high-cri area; they've never made a felony arrest; and right now they're scared shitless. Mike Welch lies on the Smiths' front lawn, forty feet awa
Welch is down!  They shot him!
We think it's the three guys who robbed Kim's.
Are civilians inside?
He said something about a girl --
Holster your guns! Another shot cracks from the house as we hear the faint w of approaching sirens.  Talley edges around his car, tryi to see Welch --
(calling) Mike!  Mike, can you hear me?
I think he's dead!
Don't shout, Larry.  I'm three feet away. Talley considers the situation and comes up with a plan -
We have to cordon off the streets, then evacuate these houses.
What are we going to do about Mike?
Keep your head down. Talley scrambles back into his car.  He backs up, then po the car up the drive and onto the front lawn --
Talley roars to a stop between Welch and the house, using car as a shield.  More shots ping off his car as Talley climbs out --
How you doing, buddy?  You still alive? Welch moans.  His shirt is soaked with blood where the bullets caught him beneath his vest.  Talley can't waste time.  The siren is closer now --
Jesus.  You hang on. Talley hoists Welch into the backseat, then dives behind wheel.  He fishtails off the lawn and up the street --
The ambulance waits as Talley powers to a stop --

He's in the backseat! Paramedics pull Mike Welch from the car as Talley gets ou He can see into the cul-de-sac from here, where Anders an Jorgenson still hunker behind their car.  Talley keys his radio --
This is Talley.  Who's on? His radio crackles with overlapping voices --
One at a time!  Clear the air! (as they settle) Louise?  Talk to me.  What do we have?
Junior Kim was DOA at the hospital. Frantic voices once more overlap --
What about Mike?  Is Welch alive?  What happened?
(forcefully) Quiet!  I want radio discipline. (as they quiet) Mike's hanging in.  Larry, Jorgy?  Listen up.
Go, Chief.
Find out who lives at four-five-five.  We gotta know who's in there.
Chief?  Mike said a young girl answered the door.
Did he say if she was shooting at him?
(hesitant) He didn't say.
Then we don't know if she's part of this or not.  Mickey, you up?
We're out two minutes, me and Dreyer.
Mike found a red pickup abandoned on Flanders.  You see it?
It's right in front of us.
Run a DMV on the plate for the owner's name.
I pulled Mickey and Dreyer off the minimart.
Jesus Christ, Louise, we can't leave a crime scene like that.  Put a unit out there.

We only have eight officers on duty, Chief. More sirens are approaching, but their help seems too lit too late.  Talley stares up the cul-de-sac at the Smiths' house as if this was a terrible nightmare --
(to himself) That's not enough.
What's that, Chief?  Say again.
Get everyone out here.  Then call the Sheriffs.  Tell them we have a possible hostage situation.
Gunsmoke fills the air.  Kevin is freaking.  He throws a magazine at Mars --
We could've gone out the back!  You didn't have to shoot!
Stop it!  They found the truck, Kev! They're already behind us!
We should give up.  All we're doing is making it worse.
Get out of our house! Her voice cuts through the din. Jennifer and Thomas are huddled with their father on the floor, Jennifer's arms crossed to cover herself --
(softly) Quiet, Jen.
Why don't they go?!  Why don't they leave us alone and go?! Dennis charges up to her, screaming and waving his gun --
Shut up!  Shut the fuck up! Walter Smith slowly stands --
None of you will get out of this. Dennis spins toward Walter, leveling his gun --
Stay down!  Stay down, goddamnit!
I'm going to my desk.
You're not goin' anywhere!  Get on the fuckin' floor! Dennis raises the gun to Walter's face.  Walter is in complete command of himself and nowhere near scared, but Jennifer grabs his legs --
Daddy, don't!
(casually; to Dennis) Take it easy, son.  I'm only going to my desk. Walter eases past Dennis, who doesn't know what to do --
Get on the floor!

I have contacts in Los Angeles.  Lawyers and judges who can help you. Walter slips open the center drawer.  Dennis thinks that Walter might go for a gun.  He screams louder and aims between Walter's eyes --
I'll fuckin' kill you!
Daddy!  Please! Walter checks that the computer disks are in the disk cas We can see their names clearly:  MARLON and AL.  He drops case into the drawer, then lifts out a thick booklet --
This is every criminal lawyer in  California.  If you give up now, right  now, I'll buy you the best lawyer in the state. Dennis slaps the book aside, even more angry --
We just killed a cop!  We killed a fat chinaman!  We'll get the death penalty! Dennis suddenly screams at Mars and Kevin --
Mars, watch the cops!  Kevin!  Watch the back of the house!
You won't die if you let me help.
Bullshit!
But if you stay in this house, I can promise you this --
(shouting over him) Shut up!  Shut up and get on the floor!
You can't imagine the fucking you're going to get. Dennis snaps.  He swings the gun hard and smashes Walter the temple.  Walter drops like a rock.
Leave him alone!! Jennifer rushes to her father's side, but Walter's out co

Talley is at his car with Anders and two other officers, Leigh Metzger, a woman in her early thirties, and Cliff Campbell, a slender guy who looks like a retired security cop.  Talley is getting information reports both in perso and over the radio --
(referring to notes) The house belongs to Walter and Pamela Smith.  They've got two kids, a girl about fifteen and a boy younger, Jennifer and Thomas.
That would be the girl who opened the door.  Are the others inside?
The mother is in Florida visiting her sister.  The father works at home, so he's probably inside. Talley keys his mike --
(into his mike) Louise?
Go, Chief.
Get a phone number for the Smiths.
(from the radio) Chief, Mikkelson.
Go, Mickey.
The truck is registered to Dennis James Rooney, white male, twenty-two.  He has an Agua Dulce address.
Contact the landlord.  I want to know employment, friends, family, anything we can find out about this guy. A news helicopter swoops overhead in a tight turn.  The c look up --
What in hell is that?

(grimly) News hawks.  There'll be more.  They monitor our frequencies. Talley realizes that his officers are staring at the helicopter as if they've never seen one; these people hav never dealt with a crime this large, and have probably ne even seen a felon.  Talley keys the mike again --

Everyone be cool.  That's our job right  now--stabilize the situation and don't  let things get out of hand.  All we have to do is hang on until the Sheriffs take over.  That's all we have to do. No one looks particularly convinced --
How do we do that?
That's my job, Metzger.  That's why I get the big bucks. Talley puts away his mike --
Jennifer and Thomas are bent over their father, wanting t help but not knowing how.  Walter's eyes flicker as if he dreaming, and the lump on his head is bleeding --
He's not waking up.  He should be awake. Jennifer abruptly stands and faces Dennis --
He needs a doctor.

Shut up and sit down.  You think someone's gonna make a house call? Jennifer is scared--really, really scared--but she doesn' sit down.  Both Dennis and Mars are staring at her.  She feels naked and vulnerable.  She crosses her arms again -
At least let me get some ice for his head. Dennis finally relents and shrugs at Mars --
Make sure Kevin isn't fucking off back there. Jennifer hurries out as Mars follows --
Jennifer goes to the counter.  Kevin is at the French doo nervous and scared; Mars is a dark shadow behind her -- She kneels to a low cabinet when Mars kicks it shut --
I thought you wanted ice. Mars towers over her, his groin inches from her face --

I'm getting a wash cloth for the ice. Mars gazes down at her, enjoying his size and power.  He steps closer, bringing his groin closer to his face. Jennifer stands, holding her arms across her breasts --
Please get away from me.

(from the background) Mars?  What are you doing? Kevin's intrusion shatters the moment.  Jennifer quickly snatches a wash cloth from the cabinet, then takes an ice tray from the freezer and brings it back to the counter - As Jennifer puts ice in the wash cloth, she sees the pari knife that she used for the sandwiches partially hidden b paper towels -- She glances at Kevin, but cannot see Mars; he's at the refrigerator behind her.  Jennifer slowly reaches for the knife --
Hey. Jennifer freezes, terrified.  She pushes the knife behind Cuisinart to hide it, then turns.  Mars is offering her a beer.
Want one?
I don't drink beer.
Mommy won't know.  You can do anything you want right now.  Mommy won't know.
What I want is to help my father. Jennifer hurries past him and disappears down the hall. as she leaves the phone starts ringing --
The phone seems to ring louder here.  Dennis stands over watching the phone as if it's alive.  The phone rings aga and again.  Finally, he answers --
Hello?
Talley is once more behind his car.  He's on his cell pho with Jorgenson nearby --
(into his phone) My name is Jeff Talley.  Is this Dennis Rooney? Intercut Dennis on the phone in Walter's office --
You with the cops?
The Bristo Police Department.  Look out the window.  You see the car? Dennis peers through the shutters --
Yeah.  I'm Rooney.
We had an awful lot of shooting.  You need a doctor in there? Dennis shoots a guilty glance at Walter, then lies --
We're cool.
Let me speak to Mr. Smith.  I want to hear it from him.
Fuck you.  I'm running this shit.  You talk to me.
How about your two friends?  You don't have a man dying in there, do you?
They're fine. Talley cups the phone to tell Jorgenson --
All three subjects are confirmed inside. Call off the house-to-house. (back to the phone) Okay, Dennis, I want to explain your situation --
(interrupting) You don't have to explain shit!  That Chinaman pulled a gun.  We wrestled for it.  That Chinaman shot himself.
Mr. Kim didn't make it, Dennis.  He died.
How about the cop?
Dennis?  I want you to release those people.
Fuck that.  They're the only thing stopping you from blowing us away.
We're not coming in there by force, okay? No one wants to hurt you.
I got these people!  You try to come get me, I'll kill every fuckin' one of them! The phone clicks in Talley's ear as Dennis slams down the phone --
Dennis is livid with fear and rage.  He paces through the office like a trapped cat --
That fuckin' Chinaman is dead!  That's murder-one, dude.  That's the needle! Kevin appears in the entry, drawn by Dennis's raving --
Get back where you belong, asshole! Mars, keep and eye on the cops; I gotta find a way out of here -- Dennis shoves Kevin out of the office and stalks after hi
Kevin dogs along beside Dennis, speaking softly so that M doesn't overhear --
I have to tell you something --
We gotta find a way outta here is what we gotta do!
It's about Mars -- They reach the master bedroom suite, a huge room with sli glass doors that overlook the pool --
That cop didn't pull his gun.  Mars lied. He just started shooting!
Bullshit.  Why would Mars do that?
I was there, Dennis!  I saw!  It's like he wanted to shoot that cop.
You're being stupid.  Check out the bathroom.  Maybe we can sneak out a window -- Dennis shoves Kevin toward the bathroom, then steps into

Kev. Kevin steps in beside him.

We're watching a grainy black and white security tape of Junior Kim's robbery/homicide.  It shows Kim behind the counter as Dennis and Mars enter --

One in front is Dennis James Rooney. Talley, Mikkelson, Dreyer, and Anders are watching the ta which is currently being played in the home of Mrs. Estel Pena, who lives two blocks from the Smiths. Mikkelson is a tall, strong woman; Dreyer is her opposite short, dumpy man --

Who's this?

Have still prints made from the tape. Show the landlord.  Maybe we can get a fast ID. Talley looks closer.  With the way Mars is positioned, we see part of the tattoo on his head --
Here on his head.  Is that a tattoo?

Says...burn it. On the tape, Kim slumps to the floor.  Dennis vaults acro the counter and runs to the door.  Mars, however, calmly picks up Kim's gun and leans across the counter.  We coul see this before, but now we see a strange smile play over face --

Chief? Talley turns.  Metzger is with Amanda and Jane --

Just around the corner and up that street.  See the helicopters? Five news choppers now hover high over the house.  The cr scene is only two blocks away.  Close.

Jesus, you're shaking. Self-conscious, Talley moves away so that he's out of rea

Jane? She turns back, her eyes asking 'what?'

A news chopper swings by overhead bringing us to the main entrance of York Estates.  The entrance has been blocked, cars are being turned away, so traffic is backed up both along the street --

Glen Howell is a nice-looking man in his early forties: Sport coat, gold Rolex, deep tan. Howell rol down the window --

No.  No, I don't know them.  Thanks for your time. Howell pulls a U-turn to get out of traffic.  He flips op his cell phone and presses the speed dial --
(into his phone) We have a problem out here.
We're in a palatial home on the ridge overlooking Palm Springs.  On the cut, Sonny Benza, Phil Tuzee, and Charli Fischer are watching TV news coverage of the situation in Bristo Camino --
Worst case, it's a bloodbath.  The detectives come out with Smith's computer, and we go directly to jail, do not pass Go.
Maybe Glen already picked up the disks.
I took the call from Glen personally. They're still in Smith's house. Fischer tries being positive --
Maybe we're getting too dramatic.  It's three kids.  They'll give up, the cops will arrest them, and that's that.  Why would they search the house?
You think we should take that chance?
(on the spot) I guess not.
I guess not, too.  How much information is in the house?
Smith was cooking the books for the IRS. That means he has it all:  The cash flow, where it comes from, how we launder it, our split with the East.
It's on two computer disks he calls Marlon and Al.
What, he's cute?  That's his idea of humor?

No way.  I tell them, that Old Man is gonna handle this from back there.

Fuck them!  Now get your head in the game, Phil--we have to handle this. Benza turns back to the television --

It's happening right now. That's exactly what Benza wanted to hear.

A low-rent motel on the road between Bristo Camino and Newhall.  Glen Howell's Mercedes is parked on the side, a with several other cars. It's late-afternoon going into evening.  The sun is sinki fast --

Married but separated, ex-LAPD.  The fam doesn't live here, but they're coming up today.  I got his address there.

How's a SWAT negotiator make it up here to this shithole?

What if it goes south?
What do you mean?

You worry about your end.  I got my side covered. Howell tucks the address in his pocket and goes to the do

A fat black desert fly, heavy with juice and thorny with coarse hair, buzzes past -- Marion watches it, only his eyes moving -- The fly lands in the sprinkles of sugar on the table -- Marion watches it, then, suddenly, with no warning, his h flashes out, slamming down on the table. On wing beats furiously; the other is broken -- Marion examines his hand.  A smear of fly goo and a singl black leg streaks his third finger.  Marion touches his tongue to the smear -- The woman behind the counter watches this, her eyes widen with disgust -- Marion holds the fly in place with his left index finger, uses his right to break away another leg.  He eats this l too -- The woman disappears into the rear -- Headlights flash across the glass, and Marion swivels aro to see Howell's Mercedes pull up -- Marion carefully pushes the still-alive fly aside as Glen Howell takes a seat across from him.  Howell puts the yel slip with Talley's address on the table --
Talley lives here.  I don't know if the place has security or not.
It won't be a problem.
He has a wife and kid.  That's how we'll get to him.
Okey-doke.
We have to own this guy, Marion.  We don't want him dead; we need to use him. Marion puts Talley's address into his pocket.
Can we make him dead after we use him? Glen Howell slides out of the booth without answering. Marion creeps him out --
Whatever you want.  Page me when you're done. Howell starts away, then turns back --
Donuts here any good?

Talley and Leigh Metzger stride through a pool of street as she reports --

Is Krupchek an aggressive guy?  Hot- tempered?  Anything like that?
Keeps to himself, more like.

(to Anders) Call the Palmdale City Attorney for a telephonic search warrant.  When you get the warrant, have Mikkelson and Dreyer search his house.
Yes, sir. Anders turns away as Metzger calls from Mrs. Pena's door

(into his radio) Louise?

Tell her I'm almost home.
Dennis is on the floor with the money, touching it, feeli it, smelling it.  Mars is standing over him, profoundly unmoved --

Who gives a shit, Mars?  Check out the cash!  We're rich.
We're trapped in a house. Mars walks away --
Dennis and Mars are returning to the front of the house, Dennis irritated at Mars's lack of enthusiasm --
We can take it with us.
You can't run with suitcases. Dennis grabs Mars by the arm, stopping him --
Then we'll stuff it up our asses.  This is the payoff.  This is every dream you ever had, all in those two bags. Mars continues on without responding, Dennis angrily following --

(from the tube) -- thought to be Dennis James Rooney. Rooney was recently released from the Antelope Valley Correctional Institute where he served time for robbery. Dennis spots himself on television and breaks into a big smile --

Jesus, first Mars, now you.  You two need anti-depressants. Across the room, Walter Smith shudders and moans; his fac swollen and covered with clammy sweat -- Jennifer is sick with worry and can't stand seeing her fa like this --
My father needs a doctor.  Please.
Hey, I've got a situation here, in case you haven't noticed.
All you're doing is watching yourself on TV.  Look at him.
Use more ice.

I'm getting a doctor! Jennifer lurches to her feet and runs toward the front do Dennis catches her in two steps and backhands her exactly way his old man used to smack his old lady, knocking her the floor --
Jen!!! Thomas charges into Dennis like an angry midget.  Kevin j between them --

Find something, Kevin.  Don't just stand there. (waves at Walter) And tie this bastard, too.  I don't want him waking up and goin' Rambo on us. Mars nods his approval.  Subtly, there is the beginning o shift in power --

You gotta pee?

Whatever.

He's just knocked out.  I've been knocked out.

You tied her like a pussy.  Make it tight. As Kevin reties the bindings, Mars rips the phone from th wall.  He smashes the phone jack with the hammer, crushin it.  Then he goes to the window and drives a heavy nail i the sill, nailing the window closed -- Mars returns to Jennifer and once more checks her binds -
Better. He tears off a strip of duct tape and presses it over her mouth --

Go downstairs, Kevin. Jennifer looks at Kevin, her eyes pleading that he not le but Kevin is cowed; he leaves -- Jennifer looks back at Mars -- Mars leans close to her.  She is terrified that he is goi to kiss her, but, instead, he sniffs, smelling her --

The cords cut into Thomas's wrists and Thomas can't reach the knots, but Mars made one mistake:  He tied Thomas to the headboard posts, and one of the newels has been loose for years -- Thomas stretches against the ropes to reach the newel, th twists it back and forth.  He works it harder and harder until the newel slides off its pin, and suddenly his hand free, though still tied to the newel -- Thomas peels the tape from his mouth, then unties the remaining binds and frees himself from the newel.  He sli off his bed and crawls along the wall to his closet --

A service hatch that opens into the attic crawlspace is b into the wall beneath Thomas's clothes.  Thomas prys open hatch, then reaches inside for a small flashlight.  He fl it on, then climbs into the eaves of the roof --

It was built for plumbers and air conditioning technicians, but Thomas has taken the space his own:  Witness the stack of Penthouse, pictures of spo heroes tacked to the rafters, and old soda cans strewn  between the joists -- Thomas scurries quietly through the tunnel, heading for -
Thomas pushes through a hatch identical to the one in his closet, then creeps to the door --
(whispers) Jen!
Jennifer twists around to see him, mumbling through the t
Sit still!  If they're in the security room, they can see you on the monitors. Jennifer quiets.  Thomas slips out of the closet and cree toward her along the wall --

I figured out what these cameras can see last year when Mom and Dad went to Lake Arrowhead.  It can't see me over here, but it's looking at you, so don't move! Thomas reaches up from behind Jennifer and jerks the tape her mouth --
Ow!  Shit!
Be quiet!  Listen! Thomas is hiding behind Jennifer so that the camera canno see him --
No one's coming.
That big asshole nailed my windows.
Mine, too.
We can use the crawlspace to get downstairs.  Then we can run for it.
No!  I'm not going to leave Daddy with them! Thomas thinks about that and decides that he can't leave their father, either --
We can't carry him.
You go, Thomas.  You get out, and I'll stay with Daddy.
I'm not gonna leave you!
Go!  If you get out, maybe you can help the police! Thomas suddenly realizes what he has to do --
We'll all go, Jennifer.  All of us or  none of us.  I know where Daddy keeps a gun. Jennifer jerks so hard that she almost tips over the chai
(loud) You leave that gun alone!

(louder) Better than you getting killed!  Don't touch that gun!  Daddy says -- Thomas slaps the tape back over her mouth.  Jennifer  struggles helplessly as Thomas slips back into the closet and is gone --

The Sheriff's Crisis Response Team rolls through the stre like an invading army:  A brown sedan leads a huge van kn as the Mobile Command Post, which is followed by a Sherif SWAT support vehicle, two SWAT Suburbans, and four radio  units. Pools of light from the helicopters follow their progress

Talley walks out to meet the lead vehicle as the convoy stops.  Up and down the row, uniformed Sheriffs pile out their vehicles and off-load their gear -- Two people climb out of the lead car:  Will Maddox, a bespectacled African-American Sheriff's SWAT negotiator, Captain Laura Martin, the CRT commander --
I'm Talley.  Who's in charge?
Laura Martin.  This is Will Maddox, the primary negotiator --
Is the perimeter around the house secure?
I've got fourteen officers on my department including me.  We're as secure as we can be.
(to Martin) Permission to deploy the line?
Do it.
(to Maddox) Don't crowd the house.  The alpha's a kid named Rooney.  He's amped up and volatile. Maddox turns away to bark orders into his shoulder mike -
Sounds like you know the job.
I've done it once or twice.  I blocked their phones to incoming calls, so you'll have to cut in a hard line to talk to  him.
(over her shoulder) Maddox!  You got that?
Doing it now!
(back to Talley) I'd like you to brief my supervisors before we take over the scene.
Whatever you want. Talley and Martin hurry toward her troops --
The garage is dark, lit only by the light that comes from kitchen's open door, as Dennis, Mars and a reluctant Kevi enter --
Someone should stay with Mr. Smith.  What if he wakes up?
(annoyed) That's why we tied him, dumbass.  Now come here and see this -- Dennis shows them a small casement window, and pushes ope the window to reveal a thick hedge --
(excited) These bushes follow the wall into the neighbor's yard.  All we need is some kind of diversion and we're home free.
That's crazy, Dennis.  The cops will see us.

Like what?

Let's burn the house. Mars says it so simply that the moment is frozen.  Mars i holding the big claw hammer, kneading it as if it was a living thing.  His face is masked by shadows, but his eye both glow as if already reflecting flame --

We see Dennis, Kevin, and Mars through a slit overhead as they emerge from the garage and move back into the house Thomas is watching them.  He has cracked open the service hatch in the laundry room ceiling to make sure that his w is clear --

The room is dark.  When Dennis and the others are gone, t ceiling hatch lifts, and Thomas lets himself down.  He sl onto the washing machine and then to the floor -- Thomas cups one hand over his flashlight and turns it on. lets light leak through his fingers so that he can see. beam cuts across a door to the garage, car keys on key ho and Jennifer's purse hanging from one of the hooks --

This is a small room off the end of the laundry with a wo bench, a stool, and shelves above the bench for Walter's hobby supplies -- Thomas shines the light over the shelves, spotting the ha plastic pistol case on the highest shelf.  That's the tar that's the goal -- Thomas uses the stool to climb onto the bench --
Dennis is in the doorway to the security closet, handing one of the money bags to Kevin --
We can't carry all this.  It's too heavy.
I've been carrying you our whole fuckin' lives. Kevin drops the bag and tries to reason with his brother
Everything we're doing is making it worse.  You can't let him burn this house. Dennis abruptly grabs Kevin by the throat, his face hard fury --

Nothing's worse than listening to you. I'm warning you, Kevin--stop holding me back.  Now you pick up that fuckin' money and get ready to go. Dennis glares at Kevin another moment, then lets go and s back into the closet --
Dennis lifts the second bag of cash when the monitors cat his eye:  The Sheriffs SWAT unit can be seen moving into position.  Dennis totally freaks --
They're coming!  Kev, Mars, they're coming!!! Dennis drops the cash and bolts out of the closet --
Mars is placing two buckets of gasoline in the hall as De and Kevin pound down the hall --
The cops are comin'!
I got the gasoline --

Get the kids!  They're our only chance! Dennis FIRES AGAIN and runs for the stairs --

Thomas is straining to reach the pistol which is a fracti of an inch beyond his grasp when he hears Dennis shouting Thomas glances helplessly at the gun case--so near, yet s far--then scrambles off the bench and --

Thomas is climbing onto the washing machine when he once sees Jennifer's purse hanging on a key hook -- Thomas jumps from the washer, grabs the purse, then scram into the ceiling as GUNSHOTS ECHO through the house --
Martin, Maddox, and her supervisors are gathered around Talley when the gunshots crack across the neighborhood --
(startled) Who's that shooting?  Martin, what's going on? Radio transmissions crackle over Martin's radio --
Shots fired!  We are taking fire on the back wall! Talley immediately knows what's happening, and he knows w
They're too close!  I told you not to crowd him!  Pull back your people; do not breach that house! Talley sprints toward the cul-de-sac --
Thomas races through the narrow black tunnel.  He slips o the rafters and almost falls through the ceiling.  He's losing precious time --
Dennis and Mars pound up the stairs, getting closer to hi room --
Thomas pushes his way into his closet --
Dennis and Mars reach the second floor --
Thomas scrambles into bed just before Dennis jerks open t door.  Dennis drags him off the bed and carries him out o the room --
Talley, Martin, and Maddox run into position behind a Sheriff's unit where a deputy has set up the dedicated cr phone -- Talley grabs up the phone --
(to the deputy) This thing good? Talley doesn't wait for the confused deputy to answer; he presses the button in the handle that dials the phone --
What in hell are you doing?  He's shooting at my men! The phone rings in Talley's ear --
(to Maddox) Then get your men off the wall! (to Martin) You breach that house, we're gonna have a bloodbath!  I know this guy, Captain -- I can talk to him.
(to Maddox) Order your men to stand down. The phone is still ringing.  Talley pulls the mike from t deputy's car and speaks over the public address --
(over the p.a.) Look out the window, Dennis.  We are NOT entering the house.  We're pulling back.
Dennis is holding Thomas around the neck, using the boy a shield.  Kevin is cowering on the floor and Mars is holdi Jennifer.  Dennis snatches up the phone --
(screaming into the phone) You fuck!  I got a fuckin' gun to this kid's head!  I'll kill'm, you fuck! Intercut Talley outside --

(still screaming) We'll burn this fuckin' place down!  I got gasoline all over in here! Talley takes a deep breath; he forces himself to speak quietly, calmly --
No one's coming in.  A couple of guys out here got carried away. Dennis peers out the front.  Talley's careful manner is calming him --
Goddamned right they got carried away. It looks like an army out there. Talley mutes the phone to speak to Martin --
(to Martin) It's over.  He's cooling off. Talley glances at Maddox.  Maddox nods, his expression sa that Talley was right --
Talley?
(back into the phone) I'm here.
I want a helicopter to take us to Mexico.
That's not going to happen, Dennis.  They won't give you a helicopter.
I'll give you these people.

(to Dennis) Hey, Dennis?  Can I let you in on a personal secret?
(hesitantly) What?
I gotta piss real bad. Dennis can't help himself; he laughs --
You're a funny guy, Talley.
I'm going to put on an officer named Will Maddox.  You talk to him for a while. Talley hands the phone to Maddox, who moves past Talley f better view of the house.  Talley looks grimly at Martin
He says he has gasoline set to burn the place.
Jesus.  He must've siphoned it from the cars.
If you go in, you can't use tear gas or flashbangs.  The whole place would go up.
(not without humor) Looks like you're bailing out at the right time.
(returns her smile) That's why you get the big bucks, Captain. Talley is moving away when his radio pops --
Chief, base.
(keying his shoulder mike)  Go.
I couldn't find Jane.  She wasn't at the restaurant.
You have her cell number?
She didn't answer.
They might be at the house.  Keep trying and let me know.  I'm going to be here a little while longer. Talley closes his phone and continues away --
Dennis and Kevin are at the television, watching an aeria view of the Sheriffs deploying around the house.  Jennife and Thomas are huddled by their father --
We're surrounded.  They're all over the neighborhood. Mars enters carrying candles and flashlights.  He lights candle and place it on a table --
What the fuck is that?
They'll cut the power. Mars tosses a flashlight to Dennis --
What about my father?
Aw, Jesus, not more of this.
Look at him!  I think he's dying!
(to Kevin and Mars) Take'm back upstairs, but don't tie'm like before.  That little fuck untied himself anyway. Dennis returns to the shutters as Mars and Kevin take the kids --

Mars shoves Thomas into the room, then lifts the claw ham For an instant, we think he's going to hit the boy--but h smashes off the door knob, instead. Mars glares at Thomas, then pulls the door closed.  The k on Thomas's side is gone; there's no way for Thomas to op the door. But that's okay by Thomas.  He waits until he's sure that Mars is gone, and then he hurries back to his closet --
Thomas pulls open the hatch, fishes out his flashlight, t dumps the contents of Jennifer's purse on the floor. He picks up her cell phone.
Talley closes his eyes with a blissful expression as a familiar sound fills the bathroom; he's taking a piss. His radio crackles --
Chief, base. Talley finishes his business, and keys his mike --
Did you find Jane and Mandy?
Could you call me back on your phone? Right away.
What's wrong with the radio?
(hesitantly) Other people can hear us.  Just call. Please.
Stand by. Now Talley is worried.  He pulls out his phone and punche the speed dial.  It rings only once -- Intercut Louise, at her desk outside Talley's office --
Is something wrong with Jane?
We have a boy on the line.  He says he's Thomas Smith and he's calling from the house.
It's a crank, Louise.  C'mon, don't waste my time with that!
His cell number belongs to the Smiths.  I think it's real, Chief.  I think this boy is inside that house. Talley worries it only for a moment --
Put him on. Talley pushes out of the bathroom into --
He flags Leigh Metzger as he cups the phone --
(to Metzger) Get Martin.  Right away. As Metzger hurries away, we intercut Thomas, hiding in th shadows on his bed, whispering so as not to be overheard
(into the phone) This is Chief Talley.  Tell me your name,  son.
Thomas Smith.  I'm in the house that's on TV.  Dennis hit my dad and now he won't wake up.  You gotta help him. Talley can tell by the tremor in the boy's voice--this is real --
Slow down, Thomas.  Take it easy and talk to me.  Was your father shot?
Dennis hit him.  His head's all big and he won't wake up.  I'm really scared.
How about you and your sister?
We're okay.
Where are you right now?
In my room. Talley hurries to a large sketch of the Smiths' floor pla laid out on the dining room table --
That's on the second floor.  Could you climb out your window if we were downstairs to catch you?
They nailed the windows.  I can't get'm open. Martin enters with Leigh Metzger.  Talley cups the phone give her the headline --
(to Martin) I've got the boy on the phone.  He's using a cell phone. (back to Thomas) What was that, son?  I didn't hear you.
If I try to climb out they'll see me on the security cameras.  They would see you outside, too -- Thomas hears someone outside his door --
They're coming! Thomas hangs up, jamming his phone behind the bed --
Thomas?  Thomas...? Talley lowers the phone --
He says that his father's hurt.
If we have a man dying in there, we'll have to go in.
They have security cameras.  Rooney would see you coming.
Did the boy say that any of them are in immediate danger?
No.  He said that his father's unconscious; he didn't say he was dying.
Then I think we should wait.  Do you agree? Talley finally nods --
You want me to stick around, I could --
You've been here all day, Chief.  Take a break.  See your family.  If I need you, I'll call. Talley looks like the most tired guy in the world.  He no his good-night, then turns away --

Talley slides into his car outside Mrs. Pena's home.  He' got a lot on his mind, and not all of it centers around 4 Castle Way.  He punches a number into his cell phone -- He listens to ringing, and then his own voice answers --
This is Jeff Talley.  Leave your name and number after the beep. We hear the beep, then --
(into his phone) Jane?  If you're there, pick up, okay? Mandy? No one answers.  Talley closes his phone, his apprehensio increasing --
The Bristo officers manning the gate swing the blockade a and wave Talley through --

The assembled television microwave vans, radio newsvans, reporters are parked together in an empty lot one block f the front gate. Ken Seymore steps into the street, speaking into a cell p as he watches Talley drive away --
(into his phone) He's leaving now.
A traffic light on the outskirts of town, deserted until Talley's car pulls to a stop --

Suddenly, two masked men point guns at his head, one from driver's side, one from the passengers.  They're wearing jackets, black ski masks, and gloves.  The man on the passenger side sports a big gold Rolex, so we'll call him Watchman --
(meaning the gun) Do you see the fuckin' gun?!  Look at it! Talley freezes.  He's been blindsided by this insane shit but he knows better than to move --

Take it easy. The man on the driver's side gets into the backseat, then Watchman gets into the passenger side.  The man behind Ta hooks an arm around Talley's throat while the Watchman  searches for Talley's gun --
Where's your gun?
I'm the Chief.  I don't carry it. The Watchman nods at the backseater, who releases Talley. A dark green Mustang roars up ahead of Talley's car.  A  second car tucks in tight on Talley's rear --
Who are you?
Follow the Mustang.  We won't go far. The Mustang pulls out, and Talley follows.

The three cars turn into the alley.  They stop, the first last cars bumper-to-bumper with Talley's.  The cars are s close to Talley that his own vehicle is pinned; he couldn drive away now even if he wanted --
The Watchman puts Talley's car in park, turns off the ignition, and takes the key.

I know you're scared, but unless you do something stupid we're not going to hurt you.  You understand? Two more masked men approach from the other cars, one com to Talley's window, the other getting into the back seat behind the Watchman.
Don't just fuckin' sit there, dumbass.  Do you understand?
What do you want?

These guys are going to take hold of you. Don't freak out.  It's for your own good. The three men take hold of Talley, the man behind again looping his arm around Talley's neck, the other two each twisting Talley's arms --
What is this? The Watchman holds a distinctive white cell phone to Tall ear --
Say hello.
Jeff?  Is that you? Talley goes berserk.  He bucks and tries to pull away, bu the three men hold tight -- The Watchman closes the phone --

(trying to calm Talley) I know, I know--she's all right.  Your kid's all right, too.  C'mon, now, relax. From this point on, you control what  happens to them. Talley can barely breathe, they're holding him so tight -
Can we let go?  You past your shock and all that, we can turn you loose and you won't do something stupid?
You can let go. The Watchman glances at the men; they let go --

Here's the deal--Walter Smith has two computer disks like this in his house. They're labeled 'Marlon' and 'Al.' The Watchman holds up a thick black Zip disk.  Talley's expression tells us that this is the weirdest shit he's e heard --
Marlon and Al....
We want them.  You will not let anyone go into that house--or anything come out-- until my people recover these disks.
I can't control what happens.  The Sheriffs are running the scene.

You will re-assume command.  In two hours, a group of my people will arrive at York Estates.  You will tell the Sheriffs that they are an FBI tactical team. The Watchman puts the white cell phone into Talley's hand
When this phone rings, you answer.  It will be me.  I'll tell you what to do. When I have what I want, you get your family.
You want . . . Marlon and Al.
I have people in York Estates right under your nose.  If you do anything except what I'm telling you, you'll get Jane and Amanda back in the mail.  We clear on  that?
These disks . . . where are they?
Smith will know. The Watchman and the others get out of Talley's car.  The doors slam shut.  The Watchman leans in --

When it rings, answer. The Watchman tosses the keys into Talley's lap.  We hear doors open and close; the cars, front and back, roar to l and speed away -- Talley focuses on the Mustang's license plate, franticall scratching down the number --
The place is deserted except for Louise, currently at her desk to monitor radio communications. Talley enters, looking as if he's stricken.  Louise can't help herself but to react --
You look terrible.  Chief, are you all right? Talley barely glances at her, going directly to his offic

Talley steps inside and peels off his uniform shirt.  He takes a bullet-resistant vest and a black sweatshirt from closet.  He straps on the vest, then pulls on the sweatsh Talley sits at his desk and lifts out a ballistic nylon pistol case from the lower drawer. He takes out his old SWAT combat piece:  This isn't a pus 9mm; it's a finely tuned .45-caliber Colt Model 1911.  On shot, one kill.  Talley ejects the empty magazine, then l it with a deadly efficiency.  He slams home the magazine Talley clips the gun to his belt under his sweatshirt.  H ready to rock.  The camera finds the photograph of Talley during his days as a SWAT tactical officer -- He was one bad motherfucker.
Talley heads for the front door --
I'm going back to York.  Have Larry meet me at the front gate. Talley exits without a backward glance --
The helicopters orbit in the distance; the empty lot with news vans is in the background. Talley turns into the development, then stops at the side the street where Larry Anders is waiting --
Anders slides into the passenger seat.  He sees a differe Talley now, focused and grim --
What's up, Chief? Talley stares at Anders, trying to decide:  Can I trust h Will he rat me out to the Watchman and cost the lives of wife and child?
Did I do something wrong? Talley gives him a slip of paper --
I want you to run this license plate and phone number.  Then I want you to find out everything you can about Walter Smith.
The guy in the house?

Go back to the office.  Run his name through the FBI and the NLETS database. I think he's involved with illegal activity or he associates with people who are. Anders glances at the slip again, then tucks it away --
Wow.  Sure, right away, Chief.
Don't tell anyone what you're doing, not Louise, not the other guys, not the Sheriffs.  You understand me, Larry?
I guess so.
Fuck guessing.  You keep your mouth shut.
I will, Chief.  Absolutely.
Get to work. Anders climbs out and Talley rockets away --
Talley pulls up behind the Sheriffs' command van.  Martin surprised to see Talley, steps from the van --
I'm re-assuming command of the scene. Martin is surprised and angry --
Excuse me?  You requested our help.  You turned over command --
And now I'm taking it back.  We're getting Smith out of the house. Talley heads for the cul-de-sac --
Jennifer is on her bed in the darkness, groggy with fear fatigue.  She hears someone outside in the hall --
Thomas? The door knob rattles.  Jennifer slides out of bed and go to the door --
Thomas, is that you? The door suddenly opens, and Mars is framed in the dim li Jennifer jumps back, terrified --
What do you want?
We can't make the microwave work. That seems so outlandish that Jennifer is confused --
What?
We're hungry.  You're going to cook. Mars grabs her hair, and pushes her out the door --
Mars shoves Jennifer into the kitchen.  Two frozen pizzas waiting on the counter --
Make the pizza.  I want scrambled eggs and hot dogs on mine.
(under her breath) How about dog shit? Mars takes a carton of eggs and a package of hot dogs fro the refrigerator --
With hot sauce and butter. Jennifer takes a bowl from the cupboard.  When she sets d the bowl, she sees the handle of the paring knife by the processor.  Jennifer breaks eggs into the bowl --
I need a frying pan.  Would you get one? Over there, under the range. As soon as Mars turns away, Jennifer palms the knife and pushes it into the waist of her shorts --
Talley joins Maddox behind the car --
What put a wild hair up your ass?

I changed my mind.  That's all you need to know. Talley picks up the dedicated crisis phone that's been cu into the Smiths' telephone line.  He lifts the receiver a presses a button.  The phone inside the house rings -- Intercut Dennis inside Smith's office.  He answers --
That you, Talley?
The one and only.  We got a little problem out here, Dennis.
You oughta try on the problem I got in here.
I need you to let me talk to Mr. Smith. Dennis shoots a nervous glance at Walter, who's twitching shuddering on the couch --
We been through that.  Forget it.
We can't forget it.  The Sheriffs think you won't let me talk to Smith because he's dead.  They think you murdered him. Maddox can't believe that Talley is saying this --
(low, so that Dennis can't hear) What in hell are you doing?!
That's bullshit!  The guy's right here! He's alive!
(pressing Dennis harder) If you don't let me talk to him, they're going to attack the house. Maddox grabs Talley's arm, his voice a low hiss --
You're gonna set him off, goddamnit! That's crazy!
(screaming) They better not! Talley pushes Maddox away and amps the pressure on Dennis
Help me keep them out!  Let me speak to Smith, Dennis.  Let me speak to him right now. Dennis is freaking.  He believes that the Sheriffs are ab to crash through the doors --
Now Talley throttles back; he senses that Dennis is at th breaking point and wants to coax him back from the edge -
(calmer; coaxing) Talk to me, Dennis.  Help me help you.  Why can't you put Smith on the phone? Dennis finally makes the admission --
(quietly) He got knocked out.  It's like he's sleeping.  He just lays there. Talley gives a thumbs-up to Maddox, who sits back in awe. This crazy shit is working --
(to Dennis) Now I understand.  That helps.  I can make them understand that.
Okay.
Let me come get him.
Fuck that!  You bastards will jump me!
If you won't let me come in, then put him outside.
You'll cap my ass as soon as I step out the door!

You've already helped yourself once, Dennis; be smart again.  If you save his life, it'll help when you get to court. Dennis is at the edge; he's looking straight down into hi deepest fears.  He finally relents --

Fuck you, Talley, fuck you!  You and one other guy, but that's it!  I want you stripped!  I gotta know you don't have guns! Dennis slams down the phone -- Talley lowers the crisis phone, then looks at Maddox --
Bring up the ambulance.

Mobile banks of flood lamps illuminate the front of the house.  The ambulance waits behind the lights; tactical officers with M5s and M16s hunker in position in case the program goes south -- Talley and a paramedic named Bigelow emerge between the lights, wearing only shorts and shoes.  Bigelow is carryi collapsable stretcher -- They stop in the mouth of the drive with a full view of t front door.  Talley lifts his cell phone --
(into the phone) Okay, Dennis, we won't approach the house until you've closed the door. The front door opens, a crack at first, then wider.  The of officers behind the lights shifts --
(over his shoulder) Easy.... Kevin and Mars waddle out with Walter Smith between them. They put him down about six feet from the front door, the return to the house --
(to Bigelow) Let's do it. Talley and Bigelow move forward.  When they reach Walter, Bigelow opens the stretcher and locks out the frame.  He peels back Walter's eyelids and flashes a penlight --
How's he look?

He's got a concussion for sure.  I'm going to brace him. As Bigelow sets a cervical neck brace, Talley gets the cr feeling that he's being watched.  He turns toward the shutters, and finds a pair of eyes only inches from his o It's Mars. Talley stares at Mars, and Mars stares back.  It's as if  they're locked in a contest of wills until --
Let's get him on the stretcher. Talley turns away to help Bigelow --
I'll support his head and shoulders.  You lift his hips and knees.  On three. Three. As they carry Walter away, Talley glances back at the eye Mars is still watching him --
are surrounded by cops as soon as they step into the shad behind the lights.  Another paramedic takes the stretcher from Talley.  Maddox is waiting with Talley's clothes --
You ready to tell me what's going on? Talley pulls on his pants --
No. Talley stalks straight to the ambulance, pulling on his sweatshirt as he goes --
A young physician named Klaus is examining Walter as Tall steps up into the ambulance --
I'm the chief of police here.  I have to talk to him.
Ain't gonna happen.  We've got unequal pupilation.  He could have an  intracranial hematoma or a fracture or both. Talley ignores the doctor and shakes Walter by the face -
Smith!  Wake up!
What are you doing?!  Stop that! Walter's eyes flutter, one more open than the other.  Tal leans closer --
(to Smith) Wake up, goddamnit.  Who are you? Klaus tries to shove Talley away, but it's like pushing a wall --
This man needs a hospital!  Stop it! Talley grabs Klaus by the arm, trying to make him see --
Use smelling salts, give him a shot,  whatever.  I just need a minute. Bigelow climbs behind the wheel and starts the ambulance. Talley pounds on the wall, shouting --

Stop the fuckin' engine! Klaus and Bigelow are both staring at Talley.  Sheriffs a Talley's own officers have gathered at the open rear of t ambulance to see what all the shouting is about -- Klaus pointedly looks at Talley's hand gripping his arm. speaks slowly, trying to make Talley understand --
I'm not going to wake him.  I don't even know that I can.
Just one question.  Please.

He.  Can't.  Answer. Talley stares at Walter Smith.  So close.  So damned clos Walter knows about the disks.  Walter might even know who Jane and Amanda.  But now Walter can't talk -- Talley turns away and climbs out of the ambulance --
As Talley emerges from the van, he pulls Metzger aside --

I want you waiting in Smith's lap.  I want to know the second--and I mean the second--that he wakes up. As Metzger hurries after the ambulance, a phone in Talley pocket rings.  He's startled and scared; it might be the Watchman.  Talley takes out the Watchman's white phone, b it's not ringing. He answers his other phone --
(into phone) Talley.
It's me, Chief.  Can you talk? Talley notices that Martin, Maddox, and the others are staring at him.  He turns away --
(into his phone) What'd you find out?
The cell phone is registered to a jewelry store in Beverly Hills.  The phone company shows no unusual --
(cutting him off) Dead end--it's a clone.  What about the Mustang?
It was stolen. Talley lowers the phone in frustration, then --
You get anything on Smith?
Chief...it's like none of this exists. I'm sorry.

Keep trying. Talley pockets his phone.  He watches the ambulance pull away, then strides back through the banks of lights to th nearest patrol car.  He grabs the dash mike and keys the public address --

(through the p.a.) Call me.  If you're safe, call me. Talley's voice echoes across the neighborhood.  Every cop the cul-de-sac stares at him.  He has addressed the house for, apparently, no reason.  Dennis shouts from his windo
I'll be safe when I'm outta here, you asshole!  I'm not talking any more! Talley drops the mike without a word and walks away --
Howell is on the phone with Ken Seymore, watching the televised news coverage with increasing alarm --
Was Smith talking? Intercut Seymore, who is reporting from the York front ga as the ambulance roars away, siren wailing --
I heard he's fucked up.  They're taking him to the hospital.
Goddamnit, tell me what you know.  Did the cops go in?  Did Smith have the disks?
I don't know.  Talley talked those punks into letting Smith out.  He's fucking us  over, Glen.  That guy is fucking us over.
What hospital?
Canyon Country. Howell slams down the phone.  He breathes deeply, taking moment to center himself.  He lifts the phone and punches number --
I have another job for you.
Talley is by himself, pacing at the curb well away from t other officers.  He is holding his cell phone.  Waiting. Finally, it rings.  Talley answers, listens, then --
Put him on. Intercut Thomas, phoning Talley in his room --
Is my daddy okay?
The doctors are taking care of him right now.  Thomas . . . are you safe?  Can you talk?
I think so.
I need your help with something.  But if you think those guys could catch you,  then I don't want you to do it, okay?
Okay.
I'm serious, Thomas; I don't want you to get hurt.
What do you want me to do?
Your dad has two computer disks.  They have funny names:  Marlon and Al.
He has lots of disks.
I think he was working on them today, so they're probably in his office.  Could you find them and see who they belong to?
Dennis won't let me go to the desk.  He makes me sit on the floor. Talley absorbs the bad news like his last best hope of sa his family is circling the drain --
But I might be able to sneak into the office if they're not around.  Then I could open the disks here in my room.
I thought they locked you in your room.
I can get into the crawlspace from my closet and climb all over the house.
Can you get into the office?
I can get into the den.  The office is right across the hall. Talley thinks about what the boy is saying, and what he'l have to do to get Marlon and Al --
If I get Rooney into the back of the house, can you find the disks without being caught?
Yes, sir. Talley glances toward the SWAT Command Van as he comes up with a plan --
Martin, Maddox, and several of her supervisors are gather outside the van as Talley approaches -- Martin sees him coming and steps away to meet him.  She's pissed off and she wants answers --
I want to know what in hell you're doing.
I'm looking for you.  I need your tactical unit.
I'm not stupid!  You can't get out of here fast enough, then you take back command; you agree to wait on Smith, then you risk everything in a stupid stunt to  get him out --
(interrupting) Don't question me, Captain!  This is my crime scene!
(shouting over him) -- then when you get him, you damn near assault the man in the ambulance!  What is going on? Talley glares at her, half-a-heartbeat from going off, an then he throttles back --

(simply) I'm a negotiator, Captain.  I negotiate. That's all you need to know.  Now are you going to help me or not? Martin weighs the determination in his eyes.  She's angry she's resentful, and she wants to knock Talley onto his a but, instead, she glances back to her van --
Maddox!  Let's give the man a hand!

Dennis steps through the double doors that open from the entry and admires the room--rich paneled walls, soft leat couches and chairs, and a lush beaten-copper bar.  Walter Smith's office is directly across the hall. Dennis saunters behind the bar, letting his fingers play the copper, then pours a stiff Ketel One on the rocks. Kevin appears behind him, watching, as Dennis takes a sea one of the leather bar stools, then peels a hundred off a thick roll and drops it on the bar --
(to an imaginary bartender) Keep the change, m'man. Dennis takes a deep drink of the vodka as Kevin approache
We're fucked.
We're fucked until we think of a way out; then we're rich.
There is no way out.
For chrissake, please!  Help me celebrate!  I figured it out!
Celebrate what?  Going to prison? Dennis enjoys another stiff belt --
No, dumbass--Talley.  Talley's the guy who keeps us in here, and Talley's the guy who can let us out. Dennis grins as if he's discovered the wisdom of the ages
Cops want to be rich like everyone else. All we have to do is share. (leans closer and lowers his voice) And if he wants someone to swing for the Chinaman, we'll give'm Mars.
Dennis. Mars is standing in the doors, large and ominous.  For an insane moment Dennis thinks that Mars has heard, but then

The food's ready. Dennis grins, then shoves Kevin out of the room ahead of the three of them disappearing toward the kitchen as -- The camera drifts up to an air vent in the ceiling, throu the slats in the grate to --
Thomas watches them leave through a hole in the air duct. When he's confident that they are gone, he continues alon the crawlspace to a service hatch that opens down into --

The "wine cellar" is a climate-controlled closet behind t bar fitted with floor-to-ceiling wine racks. The ceiling hatch lifts, and Thomas climbs down the racks the floor.  He eases open the door and peeks out behind t bar.  The den is bright with light, and empty -- Thomas lifts his cell phone --
(whispers into the phone) It's me, Chief.  I'm in the den.

Talley, Maddox, and several tactical officers are lined a the rear wall, watching the house.  Talley, with a phone his ear, is looking through a night-vision scope -- He can see into the kitchen through the French doors.  Ma and Jennifer are inside, and, as we watch, Dennis and Kev enter --
(into his phone) Okay, bud, here we go. Talley hands the scope to Maddox, then keys his radio mik
(into his mike) Captain?  Kill the lights.
Dennis and Kevin are digging into plates of pizza and egg when the house goes dark --

Shit!  It's the cops! The backyard ERUPTS; explosions from Starflash grenades J and CAREEN over the swimming pool like New Year fireworks It sounds like World War III -- Dennis throws himself behind the kitchen counter --
The house now dark, Thomas scurries to the double doors. peeks around the corner to see if the coast is clear, the darts across the hall to --

The office is lit only by the flickering candles.  Thomas checks his father's computer--no disks.  He searches thro the papers scattered over the desk, but finds nothing -- Then he opens the drawer -- The disk case that his father put there earlier is waitin Thomas opens the case -- Marlon.  Al. He found them.
The Starflash grenades burn out as Talley's amplified voi echoes into the house --
It's time to talk face-to-face, Dennis. Come out, just you, and we'll talk.
What's he doing?  What's going on?!
Mars!  They're trying to blindside us! Check the front! Mars lurches to his feet and hurries to the office --

Thomas is heading for the door when he hears footsteps co fast toward the office -- Thomas reverses course and ducks under the desk.  He pull himself into a ball and tries not to breathe -- Mars is in the room. The desk is a great oak monster, big as a boat.  It sits curvy legs that leave a gap between the desk and the floo Thomas can see feet -- The feet go to the windows --
What's going on out front? The feet turn toward the desk.  Thomas tries to squeeze himself smaller --
Mars?!  What the fuck are they doin'? The feet come to the desk --
Mars!  Something's happening!  Get back here! The feet hesitate, then, finally, walk away -- Thomas scrambles from under the desk and darts across the hall --
Talley approaches the house.  He can see flashlights movi in the kitchen --
Come on, Dennis.  Talk to me. Dennis doesn't answer, so Talley moves closer.  He spread his hands wide --
I'm unarmed.  I'm looking at you.  Get out here and let's talk. Dennis comes to the French doors.  He stuffs his pistol i his pants, and opens the doors --
You got a sniper out there, gonna shoot me?
Only if you try to grab me.  We could've shot you from the wall. Dennis considers that and accepts it.  He steps out of th house and walks over to Talley --
You've been in there a long time. What're you waiting for?
Would you be in a hurry to go to prison for the rest of your life?
I'd be trying to get the best deal that I could.
Maybe that's what I'm doing.  Can I reach in my pocket, show you something? Dennis Rooney steps closer because he doesn't want anyone else to see the wad of money he pulls out --
That's fifty hundred-dollar bills.  Five grand.  They got money in this house, Talley, more than you've ever seen. Dennis pushes the money back into his pocket.
How much would it be worth to you, getting me out of here? So that's what keeps Dennis in the house--money.  This is first that Talley has heard of the money --
You picked a bad house to hole up in, son.
Two hundred thousand cash, right in your pocket, no one needs to know.
Give up.
There's a million dollars in there, maybe two million.  I'll give you half. Talley stares at Dennis, wondering how much to tell him a whether or not it will do any good --

The man you sent to the hospital is a criminal.  He has partners.  This is their house and their money and they want it back. These simple facts settle on Dennis like a funeral shroud everything that Smith said earlier now makes a horrible sense:  You can't imagine the fucking you're going to get Dennis's eyes fill with defeat and helplessness --
It ain't been a good day, Chief.

Give up, Dennis.  Let these people go. At least you'll have your life. Dennis steps inside and pulls the door closed, the darkne in the house swallowing him like dirty water. The power is turned on.  The house comes to life -- As Talley turns away, his phone once more rings --
Thomas is hunkered with his computer behind his bed so th the camera can't see him.
I got'm! Intercut Talley, now back in the cul-de-sac --
Can you open them?
I opened Marlon.  I think it's somebody's taxes.
Look for names.  Does it say whose taxes they are? Thomas scrolls through a spread sheet --
I don't see any people names.  It's all businesses.
Try Al.  See if you can open Al. Thomas changes disks and opens Al --
Yeah!  Here's a name.  This is somebody's personal tax --
Who is it?

Charles G. Benza. (then; noise in the hall) They're coming! Thomas abruptly hangs up and the line goes dead in Talley ear. Talley recognizes the name as easily as an East Coast cop would recognize John Gotti, and realizes the stunning imp of Smith possessing Sonny Benza's financial records --
Sonny Benza.  Oh, fuck. Talley sprints across the cul-de-sac to his nearest offic Jorgenson, and keys Jorgenson's shoulder mike --
(into the mike) Leigh?  Metzger, answer me!
I'm at the hospital.
Put a guard on Smith!  I want you with Smith until I get there!
What's going on?
Get in the car.  Now. Talley drops the mike and shoves Jorgenson toward the car

Marion Clewes is stepping from his car as Talley's police unit rips into the parking lot with flashing lights -- Marion watches Talley and Jorgenson rush into the ER, the frowns and punches the speed dial on his phone --
(into his phone) We're too late.  The police are here.

We're at the end of a gravel road in the low foothills of Pearblossom, a farm community of fruit orchards in the lo foothills. A Bristo Camino police car pulls up outside a thirty-foot Caravan trailer, and Mikkelson and Dreyer get out.  Mikke lights up the trailer with the radio car's spotlight --
